article.headline: Virginia 85, Richmond 58
article.story: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. (AP) -- Virginia's move to a tougher nonconference schedule has already brought No. 18 Arizona and Richmond to University Hall this season. The Cavaliers have made both look no better than anyone else on their November schedules in recent year. They dispatched Arizona 78-60 a week ago and left no doubt who was in control on Sunday as they took command early and beat the Spiders 85-58. Devin Smith scored 26 points and Elton Brown had 12 points and 10 rebounds as Virginia rode sharp 3-point shooting late in the first half to an 18-point lead. Smith said the victory was nice, but there's still a lot to prove. "It's still early," he said. "We have to see how we handle our road games. We've handled the early tests at home but now we go on the road and we have to see how we handle those tests. We do have to protect our home court." The Cavaliers (4-0) led 47-29 at halftime, using a string of three 3-pointers to break open a close game as halftime approached. The Cavaliers then used a 14-3 run sparked by Smith's 3-pointer to expand their lead to 64-34 with 14:01 remaining. A key, Smith said, was the attention Brown was drawing inside. "When Elton is working inside, it opens things up for us outside," he said. "It's good that we are making the shots because if we don't, they can sag down on Elton." Virginia was 11-for-27 on 3-pointers, 8-for-17 in the first half. Richmond coach Jerry Wainwright was grateful for the chance to play at Virginia in the start of a two-year contract that will wind up next year at Richmond Coliseum. "Obviously it is a meaningful series for us," he said. "We are a young basketball team and we were exposed today. I think we will be more than competitive throughout the season and I think this will turn out to be a real good win for Virginia." The Spiders (2-1) never got closer than 20 over the last 14 minutes and Wainwright joked that Virginia coach Pete Gillen may have had a higher power on his side. "I knew that I was in trouble when I went to church this morning when he was there and had beaten me there," he said. "He prayed more than me today so I had no shot." Gillen's players had more than a little to do with that. Smith connected on 8 of 13 shots, including five of his 10 3-point attempts, and also grabbed seven rebounds. Freshman Sean Singletary added 11 points, Gary Forbes 10. Kevin Steenberge led Richmond with 14 points and Daon Merritt had 10. The game was the first between the schools since a 69-65 Virginia win at Richmond on Dec. 21, 1999, and was Richmond's first game at U-Hall since the 1996-97 season. Virginia gained its halftime lead thanks in large part to strong shooting from behind the arc. The Cavaliers made 8 of 17 3-point tries in the opening half, including consecutive 3s by Singletary, Smith and Reynolds that turned a 35-27 lead into a 44-27 advantage with just over two minutes to play before halftime. The Spiders had as many field goals in the half, 14, but made only one from 3-point territory and missed all seven of their shots from the free-throw line.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover
